breakdown.title: The Validation Playbook Used by Every Successful Founder

items.title: Week 1: Launch the Smoke Test
items.description: Landing page. Pricing. Payment button. That's it. If nobody tries to pay, you've saved yourself months of wasted effort. This is how Dropbox started.

items.title: Week 2: Talk to Every Signup
items.description: Call them. Email them. Learn why they signed up. What problem are they really trying to solve? Half will want something different than you imagined.

items.title: Week 3: Build the Minimum Lovable Product
items.description: Not minimum viable. Minimum lovable. Solve one problem exceptionally well. Charge for it. If they pay, you have a business. If not, pivot or kill it.

items.title: Week 4: The Go/No-Go Decision
items.description: 10 paying customers? Double down. Zero? Move on. This discipline separates successful entrepreneurs from dreamers with empty bank accounts.

conclusion.title: The $50,000 Question
conclusion.text: Would you rather discover your idea won't work after spending $50,000 and 6 months, or after spending $299 and 72 hours? This isn't about building faster. It's about failing faster. Because the sooner you fail, the sooner you find the idea that actually works.
conclusion.cta: Every successful entrepreneur has a graveyard of failed ideas. The difference? They killed bad ideas in days, not years. This template is your idea executioner. Use it wisely.

items.content: Launched 4 different ideas in 2 months. Three failed fast. The fourth hit $8K MRR in 6 weeks. Without this template, I'd still be building the first failure.
Built an AI SaaS idea I was sure would work. Zero signups. Pivoted to a boring CRM feature. 47 paid users in month one. The market doesn't care about your assumptions.
My co-founder wanted to build for 6 months. I used this to launch in 3 days. When customers started paying immediately, he finally understood: validation before perfection.

items.question: I'm not technical. Can I still use this?
items.answer: Can you edit text in a document? Then yes. You'll change some words, add your pricing, and launch. If you get stuck, the $99 guide shows you exactly what to click. Most non-technical founders launch in 2-3 days.

items.question: What if my idea fails?
items.answer: That's the point. Fail in 72 hours, not 72 weeks. The average entrepreneur wastes $50,000 and a year on ideas nobody wants. With this, you'll know in days. Failed fast? Good. Now test your next idea. Serial entrepreneurs average 7 failures before their big win.

items.question: Why not use Shopify or Gumroad?
items.answer: Those are great for selling existing products. This is for testing new business ideas. You control everything, pay zero fees, and own your customer data. When your idea takes off, you're not locked into someone else's platform.

items.question: What kind of business can I test?
items.answer: Any subscription service, digital product, or software tool. Coaching programs, AI tools, productivity apps, B2B services, online courses. If you can charge for it online, you can test it with this. Most successful tests are boring B2B tools, not sexy consumer apps.

items.question: What if I find paying customers?
items.answer: Congratulations, you have a business. Keep serving them, listen to their feedback, and grow. This same system handles thousands of customers without breaking. When you need custom features, hire a developer. You'll know exactly what to build because customers told you.

items.question: How fast can I really launch?
items.answer: Download today, launch tomorrow. Seriously. The longest part is deciding your price. Most people overthink it for days. Pick a number, launch, and adjust based on real feedback. Motion beats meditation every time.
